text: A cell culture system to monitor effector CTL differentiation
We used a simple cell culture system to examine the kinetics of effector gene expression during <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cell differentiation .

Naive <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from P14 TCR transgenic mice were activated for 2 d with anti - <extra_id_0> CD3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or with splenic APCs in the presence of Gp33 peptide , and were cultured in media containing 100 U / ml of recombinant human <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> rhIL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

We used TCR transgenic mice for these experiments because they provide a reliable source of <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells that are truly naive ; however , we chose not to stimulate cells with antigen in most experiments so as to avoid contamination with proteins and nucleic acids derived from APCs .

There were only minor differences in gene expression during differentiation induced by antigen / APC versus anti - <extra_id_0> CD3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / anti - <extra_id_0> CD28 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and the major conclusions presented in this report are the same for both activating conditions .
Under our culture conditions , activated <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells expanded exponentially and accumulated for > 8 d .
We limited our analysis to the first 6-8 d after activation , a period that coincides with clonal expansion of <extra_id_0> CD8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells after activation in vivo .
